-#####################################################################
-# Function : findConfigVersion
-# Parameters : compiler gcc | g++ 
-#              toolver qa c or qa c++ version number.
-# Description : Find configuration directories for QA C or QA C++ 
-#               that matches the compiler and ver tool version number.
-# Returns : Closest matched configuration
-#               
-#####################################################################
-
-sub findConfigVersion
-{
-    my $compiler = $_[0];
-    my $toolver  = $_[1];
-    my $found    = 0;           # true if exact match found
-    my $matchedVersion = 0;     # best match.
-    my $file;                   # current file / directory
-    my $startDir = cwd();       # which directory did we start in
-    my $lowestAvailableVer = 0; # Lowest available found version no
-    
-    chdir("${compiler}-headers");
-    foreach $file (glob("*")) {
-        if (($file =~ m/~$/) || ($file =~ m/\\.bak$/)) {
-                # Ignore backup files
-        } elsif (($file =~ m/^[0-9]+(\\.[0-9]+)?/) # valid file / directory name
-             && (-d $file)) {                     # and is a directory
-            
-            if (($lowestAvailableVer == 0) || ($lowestAvailableVer > $file)) {
-                $lowestAvailableVer = $file;
-            }
-            
-            if ((!$found) && ($file == $toolver)) { # numerically equiv
-                $found = 1;
-                $matchedVersion = $file;
-            }
-            
-            if ((!$found) && ($file < $toolver) && ($file > $matchedVersion)) { # could be closest match
-                $matchedVersion = $file; # but keep searching just in case.
-            }
-        }
-    }
-    
-    if ($matchedVersion == 0) {
-        # No version found <= specified so go for lowest available.
-        $matchedVersion = $lowestAvailableVer;
-    }
-    
-    chdir($startDir);
-    return $matchedVersion;
-}
-
-#####################################################################
-# Function : initDefaults
-# Parameters : intrinsicTypes     - reference to hash containing implicit types
-#              intrinsicWcharType - reference to scalar for implicit wchar_t
-#              typeSizes - reference to hash containing default type sizes
-#              typeAlign - reference to hash containing default type alignment
-# Description : Sets default options to be used should we not be able
-#               to determine their value from running the compiler.
-# Returns : Nothing.
-#               
-#####################################################################
-
-sub initDefaults {
-    my $intrinsicTypes = shift;
-    my $intrinsicWcharType = shift;
-    my $typeSizes = shift;
-    my $typeAlign = shift;
-
-    #
-    # Implicit types for QA C/C++ are:
-    #   size_t=unsigned int
-    #   ptrdiff_t=int
-    $$intrinsicTypes{"size_t"}="unsigned int";
-    $$intrinsicTypes{"ptrdiff_t"}="int";
-
-    #
-    # Implicit type for QA C wchar_t=
-    $$intrinsicWcharType = "unsigned short";
-
-    #
-    # Implicit type sizes for types
-    $$typeSizes{"char"}=8;
-    $$typeSizes{"short"}=16;
-    $$typeSizes{"int"}=32;
-    $$typeSizes{"long"}=32;
-    $$typeSizes{"longlong"}=64;
-    $$typeSizes{"float"}=32;
-    $$typeSizes{"double"}=64;
-    $$typeSizes{"ldouble"}=96;
-    $$typeSizes{"dataptr"}=32;
-    $$typeSizes{"codeptr"}=32;
-
-    $$typeAlign{"short"}=2;
-    $$typeAlign{"int"}=4;
-    $$typeAlign{"long"}=4;
-    $$typeAlign{"longlong"}=8;
-    $$typeAlign{"float"}=4;
-    $$typeAlign{"double"}=8;
-    $$typeAlign{"ldouble"}=12;
-    $$typeAlign{"dataptr"}=4;
-    $$typeAlign{"codeptr"}=4;
-}
-
-#####################################################################
-# Function    : fixIntrinsicType
-# Parameters  : type
-# Description : Change \'short int\' to \'int\' and \'long int\' to \'long\'
-#               as the GUIs cannot handle this.
-# Returns     : An intrinsic type compatible with the GUI
-#####################################################################
-
-sub fixIntrinsicType {
-    my $type = shift;
-    $type =~ s/short\\s*int/short/;
-    $type =~ s/long\\s*long\\s*unsigned/unsigned long long/;
-    $type =~ s/long\\s*unsigned/unsigned long/;
-    $type =~ s/long\\s*int/long/;
-    return $type;
-}
-
-#####################################################################
-# Function : scanGccOutput
-# Parameters : ph - file handle to gcc output.
-#              gccVersionFoundRef - reference reported gcc version 
-#                  stored here.
-#              sysPathsRef - reference, system include paths reported
-#                  by gcc. 
-#              omittedPathsRef - reference, system include paths 
-#                  omitted from include path list.
-#              definesRef - reference, system macros defined by -D...
-#              intrinsicTypes - reference, implicit types size_t and
-#                  ptrdiff_t
-#              intrinsicWcharType - reference to scalar for wchar_t
-#              typeSizes - reference, implicit type sizes
-#              typeAlign - reference, implicit type alignment
-# Description : Scan the output of gcc -V ... and extract the version,
-#               user include paths (if configured),  system include
-#               paths and macros (-Dmacro...)
-# Returns : Nothing.
-#               
-#####################################################################
-
-sub scanGccOutput {
-    my $ph = shift;
-    my $gccVersionFoundRef = shift;
-    my $sysPathsRef = shift;
-    my $omittedPathsRef = shift;
-    my $definesRef = shift;
-    my $intrinsicTypes = shift;
-    my $intrinsicWcharType = shift;
-    my $typeSizes = shift;
-    my $typeAlign = shift;
-    my $line;
-    my $i;
-    my $canonicalPath;   #absolute path to directory
-    my $macroName;
-    my $macroBody;
-    my $macroDef;     # PRL style macro definition
-
-    while (defined($line = <$ph>)) {
-        chomp($line);
-
-        # Look for the product version
-        if ( "$line" =~ /^gcc\\s+version\\s+([0-9a-zA-Z\\.]+)/ ) {
-            $$gccVersionFoundRef = $1;
-        }
-
-        # Look for pre-processor invocation and extract macro defns
-        # ++++ These definitions not used any more ++++
-        #if ("$line" =~ m#(/.*)*/cpp#) {
-        #    extractDefns($line, $definesRef);
-        #
-        #}
-
-
-        # Extract # defines from output and convert to macro=body
-        # command line options -E -dM generate implicit defines as
-        # #define directives
-
-        # macro with body
-        if ( "$line" =~ /^#define\\s+(\\w[\\w\\(\\)]*)\\s+(.*)\\s*$/) {
-
-            # $1 = macro name, $2 = macro body
-            $macroName = $1;
-            $macroBody = $2;
-
-            # remove trailing spaces
-            $macroBody =~ s/\\s+$//;
-
-            if ("$macroBody" =~ m/\\".*\\"/ ) {
-                # remove the quotes.  __PRL_STRINGIFY will add later.
-                $macroBody =~ s/\\"//g;
-                $macroDef = "${macroName}=_PRL_STRINGIFY(${macroBody})";
-                
-            } else {
-                $macroDef = "$macroName=$macroBody";
-            }
-
-            push(@$definesRef,$macroDef);
-
-            if ("$macroName" =~ m/__SIZE_TYPE__/) {
-                # Special handling to update intrinsic type for
-                # \'size_t\'
-                $$intrinsicTypes{"size_t"} = fixIntrinsicType($macroBody);
-            } elsif  ("$macroName" =~ m/__PTRDIFF_TYPE__/) {
-                # Special handling to update intrinsic type for
-                # \'ptrdiff_t\'
-                $$intrinsicTypes{"ptrdiff_t"} = fixIntrinsicType($macroBody);
-            } elsif  ("$macroName" =~ m/__WCHAR_TYPE__/) {
-                # Special handling to update intrinsic type for
-                # \'wchar_t\'
-                $$intrinsicWcharType = fixIntrinsicType($macroBody);
-            } elsif  ("$macroName" =~ m/__CHAR_BIT__/) {
-                # Number of bits in char
-                $$typeSizes{"char"} = $macroBody;
-            } elsif  ("$macroName" =~ m/__SIZEOF_SHORT__/) {
-                # Number of bits in short
-                $$typeSizes{"short"} = $$typeSizes{"char"}*$macroBody;
-                $$typeAlign{"short"} = $macroBody;
-            } elsif  ("$macroName" =~ m/__SIZEOF_INT__/) {
-                # Number of bits in int
-                $$typeSizes{"int"} = $$typeSizes{"char"}*$macroBody;
-                $$typeAlign{"int"} = $macroBody;
-            } elsif  ("$macroName" =~ m/__SIZEOF_LONG__/) {
-                # Number of bits in long
-                $$typeSizes{"long"} = $$typeSizes{"char"}*$macroBody;
-                $$typeAlign{"long"} = $macroBody;
-            } elsif  ("$macroName" =~ m/__SIZEOF_LONG_LONG__/) {
-                # Number of bits in long long
-                $$typeSizes{"longlong"} = $$typeSizes{"char"}*$macroBody;
-                $$typeAlign{"longlong"} = $macroBody;
-            } elsif  ("$macroName" =~ m/__SIZEOF_FLOAT__/) {
-                # Number of bits in float
-                $$typeSizes{"float"} = $$typeSizes{"char"}*$macroBody;
-                $$typeAlign{"float"} = $macroBody;
-            } elsif  ("$macroName" =~ m/__SIZEOF_DOUBLE__/) {
-                # Number of bits in double
-                $$typeSizes{"double"} = $$typeSizes{"char"}*$macroBody;
-                $$typeAlign{"double"} = $macroBody;
-            } elsif  ("$macroName" =~ m/__SIZEOF_LONG_DOUBLE__/) {
-                # Number of bits in long double
-                $$typeSizes{"ldouble"} = $$typeSizes{"char"}*$macroBody;
-                $$typeAlign{"ldouble"} = $macroBody;
-            } elsif  ("$macroName" =~ m/__SIZEOF_POINTER__/) {
-                # Number of bits in pointers
-                $$typeSizes{"dataptr"} = $$typeSizes{"char"}*$macroBody;
-                $$typeSizes{"codeptr"} = $$typeSizes{"dataptr"};
-                $$typeAlign{"dataptr"} = $macroBody;
-                $$typeAlign{"codeptr"} = $$typeAlign{"dataptr"};
-            }
-        } elsif ( "$line" =~ /^#define\\s+(\\w+)\\s*$/ ) {
-            # macro without body
-        
-            # $1 = macro name
-            push(@$definesRef,"$1=");
-        }
-
-        # Look for search paths. @ is match operator.
-        if ("$line" =~ m@^#include [<"]\\.\\.\\.[>"] search starts here@) {
-            # should be paths until "End of search list"
-            while ((defined($line = <$ph>)) &&
-                   !("$line" =~ m/^End of search list/)) {
-
-                # Identify paths and store.  Paths are indented.
-                if ("$line" =~ m#^\\s+([/\\.\\w\\\\].*)#) {
-
-                    if (-d "$1") {
-                        $canonicalPath = File::Spec->canonpath($1);
-                        push(@$sysPathsRef,$canonicalPath);
-                    } else {
-                        push(@$sysPathsRef, $1);
-                    }
-                }
-
-            }
-
-            # if we\'ve reached the end of file something is wrong.
-            if (!defined($line)) {
-                warn("\\a\\a\\a\\aWARNING - end of file reached while ".
-                     "processing search path list.  ".
-                     "The output of gcc -v may be in an unexpected ".
-                     "format.\
");
-            }
-        }
-
-        # Look for omitted search paths. @ is match operator.
-        #if ("$line" =~ m/omitted from the search path:$/) {
-        #    # should be paths until "End of omitted list"
-        #    while ((defined($line = <$ph>)) &&
-        #           !("$line" =~ m/^End of omitted list/)) {
-        #
-        #        # Identify paths and store.  Paths are indented.
-        #        if ("$line" =~ m#^\\s+(/.*)#) {
-        #            push(@$omittedPathsRef, $1)
-        #        }
-        #
-        #    }
-        #
-        #    # if we\'ve reach the end of file something is wrong.
-        #    if (!defined($line)) {
-        #        warn("\\a\\a\\a\\aWARNING - end of file reached while ".
-        #             "processing omitted path list.  ".
-        #             "The output of gcc -v may be in an unexpected ".
-        #             "format.\
");
-        #    }
-        #
-        #}
-
-    }
-}    
-
-#####################################################################
-# Function : extractDefns
-# Parameters : line - line of text containing multiple defns (-D...)
-#              definesRef - reference to array to containi definition
-#
-# Description : scan line for occurances of -D... and extract
-#               macro definition into definesRef.
-#               
-# Returns : Nothing.
-#               
-#####################################################################
-
-sub extractDefns {
-    my $line = $_[0];
-    my $definesRef = $_[1];
-    my $lineLen = length($line);
-    my $defn;                   #temporary store for macro defn.
-    my $idx = 0;                #used to index substrings of $line.
-    my $oldIdx = 0;             # continue search from this location.
-
-
-    # while not at the end of the string
-    # and there is at least one -D... remaining
-    while (($idx < $lineLen) &&
-           ((substr($line,$idx) =~ /(-D)(\\S+)/)) ||   # eg -D__SYM__=123 
-            (substr($line,$idx) =~ /(-D)(\\S+=".*")/)) # eg -D__SYM__="ABC"
-    {
-        # $1 contains -D, $2 contains macro text.
-        $defn = $1.$2;
-        push(@$definesRef, $2);
-        $oldIdx = $idx;   #The next index must be greater than this.
-        $idx = index($line,$defn,$oldIdx) + length($defn);
-    }
-
-
-    # Do exactly the same for -A\'s
-    # Format is -AMacro(value)
-    #
-    #-A\'s  Skipped in this version
-    #$idx = 0;
-    #$oldIdx = 0;
-
-    #while (($idx < $lineLen) &&
-    #       (substr($line,$idx) =~ /(-A)(\\S+)\\((\\S+)\\)/ ) ) {
-    #    # $1 contains -A, $2 contains macro name, $3 contains macro value.
-    #    push(@$definesRef,"$2=$3");
-    #    $defn = "$1$2($3)";
-    #    $oldIdx = $idx;
-    #    $idx = index($line, $defn, $oldIdx) + length($defn);
-    #}
-}
-
-#####################################################################
-# Function : getConfigVersion
-# Parameters : compiler - gcc or g++.#
-#
-#              userVersion - The version specified by the user on the
-#                command line.
-#
-# Description : Scans {$compiler}-headers directory configuration directories.
-#               each directory is named after the version against which
-#               the configuration was tested.
-#
-#               If an exact match isn\'t found, the user is prompted
-#               to select the version which closest matches their
-#               setup.
-#              
-#               
-
-# Returns : Configuration version.  The version which the 
-#           configuration template was designed.
-#               
-#####################################################################
-
-sub getConfigVersion {
-
-    my $compiler    = $_[0];
-    my $userVersion = $_[1];
-    my $toolVersion = $_[2];
-    my $manual      = $_[3];
-    my $configVersion;
-    my $dir;
-    my @supportedVersions;
-    my $found = 0;
-    my $numfound;
-    my $menuNum;     #Menu item number.
-    my $i;
-    my $choice;
-    my $confirm;
-    my $base;
-    my $dummy;
-
-
-    foreach $dir (glob("${compiler}-headers/${toolVersion}/*")) {
-        ($base,$dummy,$dummy) = fileparse($dir,\'\');
-
-        if (-e "${compiler}-headers/$toolVersion/$base/person/${compiler}.p_c.tpl") {
-
-            push(@supportedVersions,$base); # directory name without
-                                            # ${compiler}-headers/
-        }
-    }
-
-    for ($i = 0; (($i < @supportedVersions) && (!$found)); $i++) {
-
-        if ($supportedVersions[$i] eq $userVersion) {
-        $configVersion = $userVersion;
-            $found = 1;
-        }
-    }
-
-    if (!$found) {
-        $configVersion = versionMenu($compiler,$userVersion,$toolVersion,
-                                     \\@supportedVersions, $manual);
-    }
-    return $configVersion;
-
-}
-
-#####################################################################
-# Function : versionMenu
-# Parameters : compiler - gcc or g++.
-#
-#              userVersion - The version specified by the user on the
-#                command line.
-#
-#              toolVersion - QA C / C++ version number
-#
-#              supportedVersionsRef - array of supported version numbers.
-#
-# Description : Scans gcc-headers directory configuration directories.
-#               each directory is named after the version against which
-#               the configuration was tested.
-#
-#               Prompting the user
-#               to select the version which closest matches their
-#               setup.
-#              
-#               
-# Returns : Configuration version.  The version which the 
-#           configuration template was designed.
-#               
-#####################################################################
-
-sub versionMenu {
-
-    my $compiler = $_[0];
-    my $userVersion = $_[1];
-    my $toolVersion = $_[2];
-    my $supportedVersionsRef = $_[3];
-    my $manual = $_[4];
-    
-    my $found = 0;
-    my $numfound;
-    my $menuNum;     #Menu item number.
-    my $i;
-    my $choice=0;
-    my $confirm;
-
-    $numfound = @$supportedVersionsRef; # number of versions found.
-
-    # This loop is only entered if we didn\'t find a matching version above.
-    do {
-        # Display supported versions.
-        print("\
\
Version $userVersion of your compiler was detected.\
".
-              "An exact match for a configuration template was not found\
\
");
-        print("Configurations found for $compiler versions:\
".
-              "============================================\
");
-
-        for($i=0; $i < $numfound; $i++) {
-            $menuNum = $i+1;
-            print("$menuNum.\\t$$supportedVersionsRef[$i]\
");
-        }
-
-        # if in non-interactive mode, automatically make the choice
-        if (!$manual)
-        {
-            my @nums;
-            
-            $choice=0;                          # default choice for versions < min supported
-            $numfound = @$supportedVersionsRef; # number of versions found.
-            for($i=$numfound-1; $i>= 0; $i--) 
-            {
-                if (versionGtEq($userVersion, $$supportedVersionsRef[$i]))
-                {
-                    $choice =$i;
-                    last;
-                }
-            }
-            $configVersion = $$supportedVersionsRef[$choice];
-            print "\
Automatically choosing version $configVersion\
";
-            return $configVersion;
-        }   
-        # other wise we let the user chose
-        print("Q.\\tQuit configuration.\
\
");
-        print("Please select the version which is the closest match for your ".
-              "system\
".
-              "Enter a number[1..$numfound] or Q to quit: " );
-        chomp($choice = <STDIN>);
-        
-        #if choice is a number and choice is within range
-        if (defined($choice)) {
-            if ( ($choice =~ m/\\d+/) && ($choice >= 0) && 
-                ($choice <= $numfound)) {
-
-                # Check if a configuration exists for language / version
-                # combination.
-
-                if (-e "${compiler}-headers/$toolVersion/$$supportedVersionsRef[$choice-1]/"
-                       ."person/$compiler.p_c.tpl") {
-                        $found = 1;
-                        $configVersion = $$supportedVersionsRef[$choice-1];
-                } else {
-                     # Oops we support the version but not the compiler.
-                     warn("\
"."+"x 80 ."\
".
-                          "WARNING: No configuration template exists for ".
-                          "$compiler version ".
-                          "$$supportedVersionsRef[$choice-1].".
-                          "\
"."+"x 80 ."\
");
-        }
-            } elsif ($choice =~ m/[Qq]/) {
-                # Quit user cannot find an acceptable configuration.
-                unlink("test.c");
-                $!=1;
-                die("\\a\\aUser aborted configuration.\
");
-            }
-        }
-    } until ($found);
-
-    return $configVersion;
-}
-
-#####################################################################
-# Function : makeHeaders
-# Parameters : source - Source directory
-#    
-#              dest - Destination directory
-#
-# Description : Recursively copy header file directories from source
-#               to dest in a OS independent manner.
-#               
-#               THE SOURCE AND DESTINATION DIRECTORIES MUST BE ABSOLUTE PATHS
-#               
-# Returns : Nothing.
-#               
-#####################################################################
-
-sub makeHeaders {
-
-    ######  The source and destination paths must be ABSOLUTE PATHS ######
-    # This function relies on the fact that "/" is portable as
-    # directory separator for internal functions.
-
-    my $source         = $_[0];    # Source directory
-    my $dest           = $_[1];    # destination directory
-
-    my $path;     # Path, base and extention extracted from current file.
-    my $base;     # eg  /users/username/dir/file.h
-    my $ext;      # $path="/users/username/dir", $base ="file", $ext=".h"
-
-
-    my $file;     # The current file.
-    
-    my @files;    # all of the files
-
-        # have to glob files differently depending on if there
-        # are spaces in the path...
-    if (index($source, \' \') == -1)
-    {
-        @files = <$source/*>;       # no space, no quotes
-    }
-    else
-    {
-        @files = <"$source/*">;     # spaces, use quotes
-    }
-
-    foreach $file (@files) {
-        #parse filename
-        ($base, $path, $ext) = fileparse($file,\'\\..*\');
-
-        # if the $file is a directory and we can access...
-        if ( (-d $file) && (-X $file) ) {
-            # Create the same directory at the destination,
-            # add the current destination directory to the 
-            # search paths list if it\'s not already there
-            # and recursively call this function.
-            if ( !(-d "$dest/$base$ext" ) ) {
-                if (! mkpath(["$dest/$base$ext"],0,0777) ) {
-                    unlink("test.c");
-                    die ("Failed to make dir $dest/$base$ext\
");
-                }
-            }
-            makeHeaders("$file","$dest/$base$ext");
-        } elsif (! -d "$file") {
-            # Copy the file to the destination directory
-
-            if ( !copy("$file","$dest/$base$ext") ){
-                unlink("test.c");
-                die ("Failed copying $file to $dest/$base$ext");
-            }
-
-        }
-
-    }
-}
-
-#####################################################################
-# Function : getSearchPaths
-# Parameters : subHeadDir - root level directory for substiture headers
-#    
-#              substituteHeaders - Reference to array in which substitute
-#              headers will be stored
-#
-#              skipLeafDirs - if true ignore directories which contain
-#                             other directories.
-#
-# Description : Recursively scan the substitute header directories and build
-#               a list of non-leaf level directories.
-#               
-#               THE DIRECTORY MUST BE AN ABSOLUTE PATH
-#               
-# Returns : Nothing.
-#               
-#####################################################################
-
-sub getSearchPaths {
-    my $subHeadDir           = $_[0];
-    my $substituteHeadersRef = $_[1];
-    my $skipLeafDirs         = $_[2];
-
-    my $file;           # The current file.
-    my $currentPath;    # The current directory
-    my $canonicalPath;  # platform dependent canonical path.
-    my @files;          # all files
-
-        # handle spaces in dir name
-    if (index($subHeadDir, \' \') == -1)
-    {
-        @files = <$subHeadDir/*>;       # no space, no quotes
-    }
-    else
-    {
-        @files = <"$subHeadDir/*">;     # spaces, use quotes
-    }
-
-    foreach $file (@files) {
-        if ( (-d "$file") &&
-             (-X "$file")) {
-            
-            # If this dir does not contain files put it in the search path
-            if ((!$skipLeafDirs) ||                      # we don\'t care if the dir is a leaf or not
-               ($skipLeafDirs && (!isLeafDirectory("$file")))) {  # or we do care and this directory is not a leaf
-
-                $canonicalPath = File::Spec->canonpath("$file");
-
-                push(@$substituteHeadersRef, $canonicalPath);
-            }
-            getSearchPaths("$file", $substituteHeadersRef,1); # Note only dirs without files from now on
-        }
-    }
-}
-
-#####################################################################
-# Function : isLeafDirectory
-# Parameters : directory - path to directory.
-#
-# Description : True if directory does not contain any subdirectories
-#               
-#               THE DIRECTORY MUST BE AN ABSOLUTE PATH
-#               
-# Returns : Non-zero if the directory contains a non-directory file
-#               
-#####################################################################
-
-sub isLeafDirectory {
-    my $dir  = $_[0];
-    my $file;
-    
-    foreach $file (<$dir/*>) {
-        if ( -d $file) {
-            return 0;
-        }
-    }
-    
-    return 1;
-}
-
-
-#####################################################################
-# Function : configurePersonality
-# Parameters : compiler - gcc or g++
-#    
-#              version - compiler version e.g. 3.0
-#
-#              subHeadDir - location of substitute headers.
-#                  Absolute path.
-#
-#              personDir - location to place the compiler personality.
-#                  Absolute path.
-#
-#              subHeadRef - Reference. Array of substitute header paths.
-#
-#              sysPathsRef - Reference. Array of system include paths.
-#
-#              omittedRef - Reference. Array of omitted system include paths.
-#
-#              sysDefinesRef - Reference. Array of system macros.
-#
-#              intrinsicTypes - Reference. Hash of implicit types
-#              
-#              intrinsicWcharType - Reference. Scalar to the type to use for wchar_T
-#
-#              typeSizes - Reference. Hash of type sizes
-#
-#              typeAlign - Reference. Hash of type alignment
-#
-#              usePCPaths - True if we are to use paths for Windows
-#
-#              toolVErsion - QA C / C++ version number.
-#
-#              cygwin - True for a cygwin environment
-#
-#              display - If true the resulting name of the personality
-#                        name will be printed
-#
-#              gcc_options - The options used when running gcc/g++
-#
-# Description : configure a compiler personality based on a template.
-#               The template is copied as is, with the retrieved
-#               information inserted at the indicated points.
-#               
-#               
-# Returns : Nothing.
-#               
-#####################################################################
-
-sub configurePersonality {
-
-    my $compiler           = shift;
-    my $version            = shift;
-    my $subHeadDir         = shift;
-    my $personDir          = shift;
-    my $subheadRef         = shift;
-    my $sysPathsRef        = shift;
-    my $omittedRef         = shift;
-    my $sysDefinesRef      = shift;
-    my $intrinsicTypes     = shift;
-    my $intrinsicWcharType = shift;
-    my $typeSizes          = shift;
-    my $typeAlign          = shift;
-    my $usePCPaths         = shift;
-    my $toolVersion        = shift;
-    my $cygwin             = shift;
-    my $display            = shift;
-    my $gcc_options        = shift;
-    
-    my $tool = ($compiler eq "gcc") ? "qac" : "qacpp";
-    
-    my $templatePath = 
-            "${compiler}-headers/$toolVersion/$version/person/${compiler}.p_c.tpl";
-    my $line;        # Current line of template.
-    my $item;        # Used to iterate over lists.
-    my $pcPath;      # paths converted to PC format.
-    my $cygwinRoot = ""; # cygwin root path
-    my $useCygpath = 1;  # flag for wheather to use cygpath or mount method
-    my %cygwinMountPoints;
-    my @mounts;
-    
-    ######################################################
-    # The following variables are set to the appropriate
-    # syntax depending on if the personality is for QAC
-    # or QAC++.
-    ######################################################
-
-    my $forceInclude;
-    my $quiet;
-    my $systemInclude;
-    my $systemDefine;
-    my $optionalQuote;  # Quote system define for QAC, not for QAC++
-
-    my $pathSeparator;  # Use \\ on PC systems where --pcpaths is specified.
-
-    if ($cygwin) {
-        # see if we have cygpath and use that if possible as this
-        # gives best results, otherwise check mounts
-        my $tmp=`which cygpath`;
-        chomp($tmp);
-        if ( $tmp eq "" ) {
-            $useCygpath = 0;
-
-            # If the OS is cygwin replace cygwin mount points
-            # Thanks to Dedicated Systems for this improvement
-            %cygwinMountPoints = getCygwinMountPoints(\\$cygwinRoot);
-            @mounts = sort {$b cmp $a } keys %cygwinMountPoints;
-            
-
-            # translate all cygwin mount points to PC path entries
-            foreach my $mount ( @mounts ) {
-                my $cygwinPath = $mount;
-                my $PCpath = $cygwinMountPoints{$mount};
-        
-                foreach $item (@$omittedRef) {
-                    $item =~ s/^$cygwinPath/$PCpath/;
-                }
-            
-                foreach $item (@$sysPathsRef) {
-                    $item =~ s/^$cygwinPath/$PCpath/;
-                }
-            }
-            
-            # If any paths still start with "/" prepend $cygwinRoot
-            # $cygwinRoot should be returned as a reference from 
-            # getCygwinMountPoints()
-            foreach $item (@$omittedRef) {
-                $item =~ s#^/#$cygwinRoot#;
-            }
-            
-            foreach $item (@$sysPathsRef) {
-                $item =~ s#^/#$cygwinRoot#;
-            }
-
-            # and the same for sub headers
-            foreach $item (@$subheadRef) {
-                $item =~ s#^/#$cygwinRoot#; 
-            }
-            
-        } else {
-                
-            # use cypath
-            foreach $item (@$omittedRef) {
-                $item=`cygpath -w "$item"`;
-                chomp($item);
-            }
-        
-            foreach $item (@$sysPathsRef) {
-                $item=`cygpath -w "$item"`;
-                chomp($item);
-            }
-
-            foreach $item (@$subheadRef) {
-                $item=`cygpath -w "$item"`;
-                chomp($item);
-            }
-            }
-        }  # if ($cygwin)
-
-    if ($usePCPaths) 
-    {
-        $pathSeparator = "\\\\";
-    
-        # convert all path entries to PC format.  (Match op is #)
-        foreach $item (@$subheadRef) 
-        {
-             $item =~ s#/#$pathSeparator#g;
-        }
-
-        foreach $item (@$omittedRef) 
-        {
-            $item =~ s#/#$pathSeparator#g;
-        }
-
-        foreach $item (@$sysPathsRef) 
-        {
-            $item =~ s#/#$pathSeparator#g;
-        }
-    } else {
-        $pathSeparator = "/";
-    } 
-
-    if ($compiler eq "gcc") {
-        # QAC personality
-        $forceInclude="-fi";
-        $quiet="-q";
-        $systemInclude="-i";
-        $systemDefine="-d";
-        $optionalQuote="\\"";
-    } else {
-        # QAC++ personality
-        $forceInclude="-fi";
-        $quiet="-q";
-        $systemInclude="-si";
-        $systemDefine="-sd";
-        $optionalQuote="\\"";
-    }
-
-    if (! open (SOURCE,"<$templatePath")) {
-        unlink("test.c");
-        die("Failed to open template $templatePath");
-    }
-
-    if (! open (DEST, ">$personDir/${compiler}_v${version}_${tool}${toolVersion}.p_c")) {
-        unlink("test.c");
-        die("Failed to create $personDir/${compiler}_v${version}_${tool}${toolVersion}.p_c");
-    }
-
-    while (defined ($line = <SOURCE>)) {
-        # copy each line of the template and check for indicators.
-
-        $line =~ s/^(\\*.*)__PRLGCC_GCC_RUN_OPTIONS__/$1$gcc_options/;

-            # header file destination.  Then generate a forceinclude.

-            foreach $item (@$subheadRef) {
-                # Don\'t repeat the prlforceinclude directory
-                if (!($item =~ "prlforceinclude")) {
-                    print(DEST "$systemInclude \\"$item\\"\
");
-                }
-            }

-            # This could be done in the loop above but kept separate
-            # to make the personality file easier to read.

-                # The prlforceinclude directory will be added later

-            } else {
-                @forceIncludeFiles = <"$subHeadDir/prlforceinclude/*.h">;     # spaces, use quotes
-            }

-            foreach $forceIncFile (@forceIncludeFiles) {
-              # translate all cygwin mount points to PC path entries
-                if ($cygwin) {
-                        if($useCygpath == 1)
-                    {
-                        $forceIncFile=`cygpath -w "$forceIncFile"`;
-                        chomp($forceIncFile);
-                    }
-                    else
-                    {
-                        foreach my $mount ( @mounts )
-                        {
-                            my $cygwinPath = $mount;
-                            my $PCpath = $cygwinMountPoints{$mount};
-                    
-                            $forceIncFile =~ s/^$cygwinPath/$PCpath/;
-                        }
-                    }
-                } 
-

-                    $forceIncFile =~ s#/#$pathSeparator#g;
-                        # set path parsing rules for creating quiet directory
-                        # directly from force include file

-                }
-                    # write quiet option once, 
-                if ($writeQuietOption == 0 ) { 
-                        # get path component, write and set flag
-                    my $quietDir = dirname($forceIncFile);
-                    print(DEST "$systemInclude \\"$quietDir\\"\
");
-                    print(DEST "$quiet \\"$quietDir\\"\
");
-                    $writeQuietOption = 1;
-                }  
-                    # write the force include option last, so they all appear together
-                print(DEST "$forceInclude \\"$forceIncFile\\"\
");
-            }
-        }
-
-        # gcc include directories or CR 965 #include_next difficiency
-        if (($line =~ /^\\*\\s*gcc\\s*include\\s*directories.*/i) ||
-            ($line =~ /^\\*\\s*cr\\s*965.*/i)) {
-
-            foreach $item (@$omittedRef) {
-
-                print(DEST "$systemInclude \\"$item\\"\
");
-            }
-
-            foreach $item (@$sysPathsRef) {
-                print(DEST "$systemInclude \\"$item\\"\
");
-            }
-
-            # do -quiet includes for include directories.
-            if ($line =~ /^\\*\\s*gcc\\s*include\\s*directories.*/i) {
-                foreach $item (@$omittedRef) {
-
-                    print(DEST "$quiet \\"$item\\"\
");
-                }
-
-                foreach $item (@$sysPathsRef) {
-
-                    print(DEST "$quiet \\"$item\\"\
");
-                }
-
-            }
-        }
-
-        # Implicit macros
-        if ($line =~ /^\\*\\s*implicit\\s*macros.*/i) {
-            print(DEST "$systemDefine ${optionalQuote}_PRL_STRINGIFY(x)=#x".
-                       "$optionalQuote\
");
-            foreach $item (@$sysDefinesRef) {
-

-                           "$optionalQuote\
");
-            }
-        }

-            foreach $item (keys %$intrinsicTypes) {
-                print(DEST "-it \\"" . $item . "=" . $$intrinsicTypes{$item} . "\\"\
");
-            }
-        }

-        # Intrinsic wchar type (only for gcc personalities)

");
-        }

");
-            }
-

-                print(DEST "-align " . $item . "=" . $$typeAlign{$item} . "\
");
-            }
-        }
-    }
-
-    close(SOURCE);
-    close(DEST);
-    if ($display != 0)
-    {
-        print("[[$personDir/${compiler}_v${version}_${tool}${toolVersion}.p_c]]\
");
-    }
-}
-
-#####################################################################
-# Function : getCygwinMountPoints
-# Parameters : cygwinRootRef - when the pc path to the cygwin root is
-#               found it is stored here for use later in
-#               mapping cygwin paths to pc paths
-#
-# Description : Map cygwin mount points by capturing the output of 
-#               the cygwin mount command
-#               information inserted at the indicated points.
-#               Extracts paths from lines such as
-#               c: on /cygdrive/c type user (textmode,noumount)
-#               C:\\cygwin\\bin on /usr/bin type ntfs (binary,auto)
-#               Note from Cygwin 1.7 the mount command reports:
-#               C:/cygwin/bin on /usr/bin type ntfs (binary,auto)
-#               i.e. with forward slashes, so the regex now does both
-#               
-# Returns : Map of cygwin mounts.  Key is cygwin path
-#               
-#####################################################################
-sub  getCygwinMountPoints
-{
-    my $cygwinRootRef = $_[0];
-    my %cygwinMountPoints = ();
-    my @mountOutput = `mount`;
-    my $line;
-
-    foreach $line (@mountOutput)
-    {
-        # Look for search paths. @ is match operator.
-   
-        if ( "$line" =~ m@^([a-z:\\\\/]+)\\s+on\\s+([a-zA-Z0-9/]*)\\s@  ||
-             "$line" =~ m@^([a-zA-Z0-9:\\\\/]+)\\s+on\\s+([/])\\s@) # root 
-    {
-        my $PCpath = $1;
-        my $cygwinPath = $2;
-        
-        # the root mount needs a "\\" added
-        if ( $cygwinPath =~ m@^[/]$@ )
-        {
-            # Make a note of this path and pass back as ref
-               $PCpath = $PCpath."\\\\";
-               $$cygwinRootRef = $PCpath;
-        }  
-
-#        printf "%-20s mounted at %s\
\
", $cygwinPath, $PCpath;
-        
-            $cygwinMountPoints{ $cygwinPath } = $PCpath;
-        }
-    }
-
-    return %cygwinMountPoints;
-}
-# Chop up a version number into Major.Minor.Release components
-sub getVersions
-{
-    my $ver = $_[0];
-    my $maj="0";
-    my $min="0";
-    my $rel="0";
-    my @nums;
-    my $len;
-    
-    @nums = split(/\\./, $ver);
-    $len = @nums;
-    if($len > 0)
-    {
-        $maj = $nums[0];
-    }
-    if($len > 1)
-    {
-        $min = $nums[1];
-    }
-    if($len > 2)
-    {
-        $rel = $nums[2];
-    }
-    return ($maj, $min, $rel);
-}
-#return 1 if the the version on lhs is greater than or equal to rhs
-sub versionGtEq
-{
-    my $lhs = $_[0];
-    my $rhs = $_[1];
-    
-    my $lhsmaj;
-    my $lhsmin;
-    my $lhsrel;
-    my $rhsmaj;
-    my $rhsmin;
-    my $rhsrel;
-    ($lhsmaj, $lhsmin, $lhsrel) = getVersions($lhs);
-    ($rhsmaj, $rhsmin, $rhsrel) = getVersions($rhs);
-    
-    if ($lhsmaj > $rhsmaj)
-    {
-        return 1;
-    }
-    if ($lhsmaj < $rhsmaj)
-    {
-        return 0;
-    }
-    # majors the same, check minor
-    if ($lhsmin > $rhsmin)
-    {
-        return 1;
-    }
-    if ($lhsmin < $rhsmin)
-    {
-        return 0;
-    }
-    #minor same, check rel
-    if ($lhsrel > $rhsrel)
-    {
-        return 1;
-    }
-    if ($lhsrel < $rhsrel)
-    {
-        return 0;
-    }
-    # rel same, return true
-    return 1;
-}

-\x0c                                                                                                      THE PROBLEM
-
-1. THE PROBLEM
-
-The compiler personality files for QA\xc2\xb7C and QA\xc2\xb7C++ can define implicit types, parsing extensions, extension
-keywords which allow the parser to analyze source code or include files which are compliant with the
-compiler.
-The compiler personality is also the place to specify search paths for system include files, implicitly defined
-macros and substitute header files which may be necessary if the header files supplied with a compiler are too
-non-compliant to allow parsing.
-This last group of attributes prevents Programming Research from providing a GNU C / C++ compiler
-personality out of the box. The system include paths and implicitly defined macros are system dependent and
-it may be necessary to provide a set of substitute headers to allow for nonstandard compiler constructs.
-Further still it may be necessary to supply a file which is always included to define implicit types or macros
-which are too complex for a simple personality file.
-
-1.1 System Include Paths and Implicit System Defines
-
-GNU C/C++ (gcc and g++ from now on) can provide some of the information we need while compiling a
-source file. The configuration script will temporarily create a dummy source file in its installation directory and
-extract this information.
-
-1.2 Substitute Header Files
-
-Programming Research may need to supply substitute header files, which are used for analysis. The
-configuration script allows you to specify where these may go although a directory structure within the
-specified destination directory may have to be enforced.
-
-\xc2\xa9 2012 Programming Research Ltd  4
-\x0c                                                                         UNPACKING YOUR INSTALLATION
-
-2. UNPACKING YOUR INSTALLATION
-
-The received configuration package will contain a file named prlgcc_4.1.zip. This file can be unpackaged as
-follows on UNIX (or in a UNIX like environment on Windows):
-
-    $ unzip prlgcc_4.1.zip
-
-This will create a prlgcc directory containing the script, User Guide and template directories.
-On Windows, different commercial unzipping programs can be used or files may be extracted directly by using
-Windows Explorer.
-
-2.1 Directory Structure
-
-The directory structure is illustrated in the diagram below:
-
-\xc2\xa9 2012 Programming Research Ltd  5
-\x0c\xc2\xa9 2012 Programming Research Ltd  6
-\x0cThe top-level gcc directory contains the configuration script prlgcc.pl. The Windows package also contains a
-compiled version of prlgcc.exe in the same location. The subdirectories gcc-headers and g++-headers contain
-a series of directories that correspond to the version numbers of supported Programming Research products.
-These directories contain sub-directories which correspond to the version numbers of supported GNU
-compilers.
-
-For example, to find a matching configuration for QA\xc2\xb7C 4.5.2, only the \xe2\x80\x9cmajor.minor\xe2\x80\x9d part of the version
-number (in this case 4.5) is required. In this case we have a match. However, if version 5.0 is specified, then
-the highest numbered configuration less than 5.0 will be used as a match. If version 4.4.2 is specified, then
-the lowest numbered configuration will be used as the closest match.
-
-Each of the version directories contain the same structure. A person directory will contain the templates for
-gcc and/or g++ compiler personalities. These templates follow a fixed naming convention. If the corresponding
-template does not exist, it is assumed that the compiler is not yet supported.
-
-The header directory contains optional QA\xc2\xb7C and QA\xc2\xb7C++ forceinclude header files. Any other files /
-directories are assumed to be substitute headers. The directory structures are copied to the location specified
-by the user when prlgcc.pl is run.
-
-\xc2\xa9 2012 Programming Research Ltd  7
-\x0c                                                                     USING THE CONFIGURATION SCRIPT
-                                                                                                               PRLGCC
-
-3. USING THE CONFIGURATION SCRIPT PRLGCC
-
-3.1 prlgcc.pl or prlgcc.exe on Windows?
-
-The Windows package contains two versions of the configuration script: a PERL version (prlgcc.pl) and a
-compiled executable version (prlgcc.exe). The choice of which one to use depends on the environment in
-which your GCC compiler runs in. If your compiler is a native Windows version (that is, it was compiled for
-Windows and runs using only the standard Windows dlls - for example MINGW GCC), then you must use
-prlgcc.exe. If your compiler is a Cygwin compiler, then you must use prlgcc.pl.
-Both versions take the same parameters; in the following sections prlgcc.pl can be substituted with prlgcc.exe
-as required.
-
-    3.1.1 Usage on Cygwin
-
-     The PERL script detects if it is being run on Cygwin and will substitute Cygwin mount points for include
-     paths in the compiler personality where necessary. It will also detect the Cygwin root directory and replace
-     paths such as
-
-         /usr/include
-
-      with
-
-         c:\\cygwin\\usr\\include
-
-    Assuming that your c:\\cygwin is the Cygwin root directory.
-    Note:
-
-        Some directories available within Cygwin may not be visible directly from DOS / Windows - and hence
-        QA\xc2\xb7C/QA\xc2\xb7C++ will not be able to see them. Prlgcc will convert these paths to full paths accessible from
-        Windows.
-
-3.2 Usage
-
-The prlgcc.pl script has the following usage:
-
-    prlgcc.pl <qac|qacpp|qac++> -personalities <personality_file_dir> [-version <product
-    version no>] [-compiler compiler_exe] [-headers <substitute_header_dir>] [-pcpaths] [-
-    manual] [-display]
-
-The options can be specified with the minimum letters that make the option unique, for example:
-
-    prlgcc.pl <qac|qacpp|qac++> -v <product version no> -h <substitute_header_dir> -pe
-    <personality_file_dir> [-c compiler_exe] [-pc]
-
-Typical usage for gcc on UNIX would be:
-
-\xc2\xa9 2012 Programming Research Ltd  8
-\x0c                                                                     USING THE CONFIGURATION SCRIPT
-                                                                                                               PRLGCC
-
-    ./prlgcc.pl QAC -pe /opt/PRQA/QAC-8.0-R/personalities
-
-For Cygwin typical usage would be:
-
-    ./prlgcc.pl QAC -pe /cygdrive/C/Program\\ Files/PRQA/QAC-8.0-R/personalities
-
-3.3 Parameters
-
-This section describes the PRLGCC parameters in more detail.
-
-    3.3.1 Product Option
-
-     The first option to prlgcc.pl must be the product. It can be qac, qacpp or qac++ (or upper case equivalent).
-     This tells the script to generate a personality with attributes for QA\xc2\xb7C or QA\xc2\xb7C++ and integrate the
-     appropriate GNU C or GNU C++ compiler.
-     This parameter is mandatory.
-
-    3.3.2 -personalities, -pe
-
-     This parameter is the location to store the generated personality file. The directory specified must be an
-     absolute path: relative paths are not accepted.
-     This can be (but doesn\xe2\x80\x99t have to be) the same directory as the -headers parameter.
-     This parameter is mandatory.
-
-    3.3.3 -version, -v
-
-     The QA\xc2\xb7C++ version number e.g. 2.0, 3.0, etc.
-     This parameter is not required when the Product options is set to \xe2\x80\x98qac\xe2\x80\x99.
-     This parameter is required only when the Product Option is set to \xe2\x80\x98qacpp\xe2\x80\x99 or \xe2\x80\x98qac++\xe2\x80\x99 and the version is 2.0
-     or previous. The default is to generate a personality compatible with QA\xc2\xb7C++ 3.0 onwards.
-
-    3.3.4 -compiler, -c
-
-     Without this parameter prlgcc.pl will run either gcc or g++ depending on the product parameter. However,
-     most cross compiler variants of gcc/g++ have the target name encoded into the compiler executable.
-     Additionally there may be several different gcc/g++ compilers installed for various targets (including the
-     native one). This parameter is used to give the name of the compiler that the personality should be
-     generated for. It can either be just the compiler name if it is on the path or the full path to the compiler
-     executable.
-     This parameter is optional.
-
-\xc2\xa9 2012 Programming Research Ltd  9
-\x0c                                                                     USING THE CONFIGURATION SCRIPT
-                                                                                                               PRLGCC
-
-    3.3.5 -headers, -h
-
-     This parameter specifies the directory in which substitute header files should be stored. The directory
-     specified must be an absolute path: relative paths are not accepted.
-     When running the script, it is important not to specify a directory above in which the script was unpacked,
-     e.g. the directory one level above the directory containing the script. After the substitute headers are
-     copied, this directory is searched recursively to build the list of substitute header files. This will result in a
-     long list containing substitute headers for every supported version of the compiler.
-     The best solution is to create a directory for the substitute headers and then to specify that to the
-     configuration script - see the -personalities parameter section.
-     If this parameter is not specified, the headers will be placed in the directory specified by the -personalities
-     option.
-
-    3.3.6 -pcpaths (optional)
-
-     This parameter is implied when the script is run under Cygwin.
-     Compilers under Cygwin or other Unix-like environments will report include directories of the form:
-
-           /usr/include
-
-    On Windows, QA\xc2\xb7C and QA\xc2\xb7C++ require Windows paths. The -pcpaths option converts unix style paths
-    (see above) to Windows equivalent (see below):
-
-         C:\\cygwin\\usr\\include
-
-    The script will also detect if any paths reported by the compiler are symbolic links (which QA\xc2\xb7C and
-    QA\xc2\xb7C++ cannot follow) and convert these to the full Windows paths.
-    This parameter is optional.
-
-   3.3.7 -manual
-
-    By default, prlgcc runs in a non-interactive way, choosing sensible default options where there is a choice.
-    The -manual option causes prlgcc to stop and request information from the user where a decision is
-    required.
-
-   3.3.8 -display
-
-    This option makes prlgcc prints out the full path to the created personality in double square brackets after it
-    is generated. This option is useful when running prlgcc from a script.
-
-3.4 Script Operation
-
-If the -compiler option is not specified, the script will use the first gcc or g++ it finds on the path. If you have
-more than one version installed, ensure that the version you want to use is the first one in your search path or
-use the -compiler option.
-
-\xc2\xa9 2012 Programming Research Ltd  10
-\x0c                                                                     USING THE CONFIGURATION SCRIPT
-                                                                                                               PRLGCC
-
-If the version of the compiler does not match one of the configuration templates and -manual is not set,
-PRLGCC will automatically choose the nearest version below the version found. However when -manual is
-set, PRLGCC will provide the list of available versions from which a configuration can be selected.
-
-Note:
-
-    The -manual option should only be used if the personality created by the automatic method is invalid
-
-    Version 3.2 of your compiler was detected.
-    An exact match for a configuration template was not found
-    Configurations found for g++ versions:
-    ============================================
-    1. 2.96
-    2. 3.0
-    3. 3.1
-    Q. Quit configuration.
-    Please select the version which is the closest match for your system
-    Enter a number[1..3] or Q to quit: 3
-
-At this point you can enter Q to quit without generating a personality or choose the number to the left of the
-configuration version, in which case a personality will be generated for that configuration.
-
-A complete session could look something like this.
-
-    Version 3.2 of your compiler was detected.
-    An exact match for a configuration template was not found
-    Configurations found for g++ versions:
-    ============================================
-    1. 2.96
-    2. 3.0
-    3. 3.1
-    Q. Quit configuration.
-    Please select the version which is the closest match for your system
-    Enter a number[1..3] or Q to quit: 3
-    Creating configuration for g++(3.2) using g++(3.1) template.
-    Creating substitute headers.
-    Substitute headers completed.
-    Configuring compiler personality.
-    Compiler personality configuration complete.
-
-Upon completion your gcc/g++ compiler personality will be generated in the specified personality directory.
-The substitute headers will be copied to their new location and this will be registered in the personality file. If
-you need to change the location of these files in the future, you will need to edit the personality either directly
-or through the appropriate user interface.
-
-Depending on the configuration, a \xe2\x80\x9cforceinclude\xe2\x80\x9d file may have been necessary. This is a file that is silently
-included before any other source files are parsed by QA\xc2\xb7C/QA\xc2\xb7C++. If this was necessary, it will be located at
-the prlforceinclude directory within the header file subdirectory.
-
-Additional substitute headers may also be created, possibly in a directory structure. These headers are
-included instead of the compiler header files.
-
-\xc2\xa9 2012 Programming Research Ltd  11
-\x0c                                                                             Using Your Compiler Personality
-
-4. Using Your Compiler Personality
-
-The generated personality can be used like any other compiler personality. This can be in the GUI, on the
-command line or in an integration. Refer to the QA\xc2\xb7C/QA\xc2\xb7C++ documentation for more information on how to
-do this.
-
-4.1 Limitations
-
-Although the script attempts to gather all the settings from the compiler output, in some cases this may be
-incomplete or inaccurate (especially on cross compilers). The generated personality can be edited either
-directly in a text editor or by opening it in the QA\xc2\xb7C/QA\xc2\xb7C++ GUI.
-
-4.2 Moving The Personality
-
-The generated personality will contain absolute paths to the compiler include directories, force include files
-and substitute header directories. If you decide to relocate the personality then it is strongly advised that you
-move the force include and substitute header directories with the personality and modify the entries in the
-personality to reflect the new location.
-
-\xc2\xa9 2012 Programming Research Ltd  12
-\x0c                                                                    Change History
-
-5. Change History
-
-The following tables summarize the change requests (CRs) that have been implemented in PRLGCC.
-CRs have been categorized into 3 types (column \xe2\x80\x9cT\xe2\x80\x9d):
-
-          C - A significant change has been implemented to the existing behavior.
-          F - A fix of a bug or problem feature.
-          N - New functionality has been introduced.
-Some CRs are associated with more than one category and in some cases; the distinction between categories
-is a little indistinct. The classification should therefore be treated as a guide only.
-
-5.1 Version 3.0
-
-5.1.1 Change Requests
-
-CR  T Description
-
-12298 F          prlgcc does not resolve symbolically linked directories or mount points on Windows. All
-                 Cygwin paths are now converted to full Windows paths.
-
-5.2 Version 4.0
-
-This release is used by and packaged into the Quick Start Utility.
-
-5.2.1 Change Requests
-
-CR  T Description
-
-14328 N          prlgcc generated personalities do not work with MINGW32 GCC. The force include files
-                 have been modified to be compatible with the MINGW compiler.
-
-14134 F          prlgcc should not fail when the prlforceinclude directory already exists. The script now
-                 creates the directory if it does not exist.
-
-14093 N          Make prlgcc run in non-interactive way. The script now runs without prompting the user
-                 - though this behaviour can be reverted using the - manual option.
-
-13954 N          Everybody uses the wrong setting for -headers in prlgcc. Many users set the -headers
-                 setting to the gcc-headers directory rather than the output location for any substitute
-                 headers. This is now optional and defaults to the same location as the -personalities
-                 setting.
-
-13953 F          prlgcc does not run well on Windows. A compiled Windows version of the script is now
-                 shipped in the package for native Windows compilers.
-
-                                                                    \xc2\xa9 2012 Programming Research Ltd  13
-\x0c5.3 Version 4.1
-
-5.3.1 Change Requests
-
-CR     T Description
-
-11869  F  The G++ \'typeof\' keyword can now be emulated using the C++ 11 decltype language
-          feature.
-
-14529 F Support added for \'__asm\'.
-
-15545  N  Updates to support new features and fixes in QA\xc2\xb7C 8.1 and QA\xc2\xb7C++ 3.0.1 including
-          improvements in support for recent versions of GCC (<=4.7.1) and BOOST C++ libraries.
-
-15834  C  PRLGCC now automatically detects the intrinsic type for size_t, ptrdiff_t and wchar_t as
-          well as determining the correct size and alignments for the fundamental types.
-
-15835 C Remove support for QA\xc2\xb7C++ 1.4.
-
-                                        \xc2\xa9 2012 Programming Research Ltd  14

-# This file serves as a global blacklist. You can list here the paths of any C files or directories
-# that should always be excluded from any MISRA analysis. It is recommended that any paths listed
-# here are rooted in one of the symbolic path variables provided by the build tooling. Any relative

-/* Linker file for GNU C Compiler */
-
-/* Entry Point */
-ENTRY(Reset_Handler)
-
-HEAP_SIZE  = DEFINED(__heap_size__)  ? __heap_size__  : 0x00000100;
-STACK_SIZE = DEFINED(__stack_size__) ? __stack_size__ : 0x00000100;
-
-/* Specify the memory areas */
-MEMORY
-{
-  m_interrupts          (RX)  : ORIGIN = 0x00000000, LENGTH = 0x00000100
-  m_flash_config        (RX)  : ORIGIN = 0x00000400, LENGTH = 0x00000010
-  m_text                (RX)  : ORIGIN = 0x00000410, LENGTH = 0x0000FBF0
-  m_data                (RW)  : ORIGIN = 0x1FFFFC00, LENGTH = 0x00001000
-}
-
-/* Define output sections */
-SECTIONS
-{
-  /* The startup code goes first into internal flash */
-  .interrupts :
-  {
-    __VECTOR_TABLE = .;
-    . = ALIGN(4);
-    KEEP(*(.isr_vector))     /* Startup code */
-    . = ALIGN(4);
-  } > m_interrupts
-
-
-  .flash_config :
-  {
-    . = ALIGN(4);
-    KEEP(*(.FlashConfig))    /* Flash Configuration Field (FCF) */
-    . = ALIGN(4);
-  } > m_flash_config
-
-  /* The program code and other data goes into internal flash */
-  .text :
-  {
-    . = ALIGN(4);
-    *(.text)                 /* .text sections (code) */
-    *(.text*)                /* .text* sections (code) */
-    *(.rodata)               /* .rodata sections (constants, strings, etc.) */
-    *(.rodata*)              /* .rodata* sections (constants, strings, etc.) */
-    *(.glue_7)               /* glue arm to thumb code */
-    *(.glue_7t)              /* glue thumb to arm code */
-    *(.eh_frame)
-    KEEP (*(.init))
-    KEEP (*(.fini))
-    . = ALIGN(4);
-  } > m_text
-
-  .ARM.extab :
-  {
-    *(.ARM.extab* .gnu.linkonce.armextab.*)
-  } > m_text
-
-  .ARM :
-  {
-    __exidx_start = .;
-    *(.ARM.exidx*)
-    __exidx_end = .;
-  } > m_text
-
- .ctors :
-  {
-    __CTOR_LIST__ = .;
-    /* gcc uses crtbegin.o to find the start of
-       the constructors, so we make sure it is
-       first.  Because this is a wildcard, it
-       doesn\'t matter if the user does not
-       actually link against crtbegin.o; the
-       linker won\'t look for a file to match a
-       wildcard.  The wildcard also means that it
-       doesn\'t matter which directory crtbegin.o
-       is in.  */
-    KEEP (*crtbegin.o(.ctors))
-    KEEP (*crtbegin?.o(.ctors))
-    /* We don\'t want to include the .ctor section from
-       from the crtend.o file until after the sorted ctors.
-       The .ctor section from the crtend file contains the
-       end of ctors marker and it must be last */
-    KEEP (*(EXCLUDE_FILE(*crtend?.o *crtend.o) .ctors))
-    KEEP (*(SORT(.ctors.*)))
-    KEEP (*(.ctors))
-    __CTOR_END__ = .;
-  } > m_text
-
-  .dtors :
-  {
-    __DTOR_LIST__ = .;
-    KEEP (*crtbegin.o(.dtors))
-    KEEP (*crtbegin?.o(.dtors))
-    KEEP (*(EXCLUDE_FILE(*crtend?.o *crtend.o) .dtors))
-    KEEP (*(SORT(.dtors.*)))
-    KEEP (*(.dtors))
-    __DTOR_END__ = .;
-  } > m_text
-
-  .preinit_array :
-  {
-    PROVIDE_HIDDEN (__preinit_array_start = .);
-    KEEP (*(.preinit_array*))
-    PROVIDE_HIDDEN (__preinit_array_end = .);
-  } > m_text
-
-  .init_array :
-  {
-    PROVIDE_HIDDEN (__init_array_start = .);
-    KEEP (*(SORT(.init_array.*)))
-    KEEP (*(.init_array*))
-    PROVIDE_HIDDEN (__init_array_end = .);
-  } > m_text
-
-  .fini_array :
-  {
-    PROVIDE_HIDDEN (__fini_array_start = .);
-    KEEP (*(SORT(.fini_array.*)))
-    KEEP (*(.fini_array*))
-    PROVIDE_HIDDEN (__fini_array_end = .);
-  } > m_text
-
-  __etext = .;    /* define a global symbol at end of code */
-  __DATA_ROM = .; /* Symbol is used by startup for data initialization */
-
-  /* reserve MTB memory at the beginning of m_data */
-  .mtb : /* MTB buffer address as defined by the hardware */
-  {
-    . = ALIGN(8);
-    _mtb_start = .;
-    KEEP(*(.mtb_buf)) /* need to KEEP Micro Trace Buffer as not referenced by application */
-    . = ALIGN(8);
-    _mtb_end = .;
-  } > m_data
-
-  .data : AT(__DATA_ROM)
-  {
-    . = ALIGN(4);
-    __DATA_RAM = .;
-    __data_start__ = .;      /* create a global symbol at data start */
-    *(.data)                 /* .data sections */
-    *(.data*)                /* .data* sections */
-    KEEP(*(.jcr*))
-    . = ALIGN(4);
-    __data_end__ = .;        /* define a global symbol at data end */
-  } > m_data
-
-  /* Symbol is used by startup for data initialization */
-  __DATA_END = __DATA_ROM + (__data_end__ - __data_start__);
-
-  /* Uninitialized data section */
-  .bss :
-  {
-    /* This is used by the startup in order to initialize the .bss section */
-    . = ALIGN(4);
-    __START_BSS = .;
-    __bss_start__ = .;
-    *(.bss)
-    *(.bss*)
-    *(COMMON)
-    . = ALIGN(4);
-    __bss_end__ = .;
-    __END_BSS = .;
-  } > m_data
-
-  .heap :
-  {
-    . = ALIGN(8);
-    __end__ = .;
-    PROVIDE(end = .);
-    __HeapBase = .;
-    . += HEAP_SIZE;
-    __HeapLimit = .;
-  } > m_data
-
-  .stack :
-  {
-    . = ALIGN(8);
-    . += STACK_SIZE;
-  } > m_data
-
-  __StackTop   = .;
-  __StackLimit = __StackTop - STACK_SIZE;
-  PROVIDE(__stack = __StackTop);
-
-  .ARM.attributes 0 : { *(.ARM.attributes) }
-}
